causes: Napoleon Bonaparte's desire to expand French control over Spain and Portugal as part of his larger plan to dominate Europe.
The deposition of the Spanish Bourbon monarchy and the installation of Napoleon's brother, Joseph Bonaparte, as king of Spain.
The resistance of the Spanish and Portuguese peoples to French occupation, supported by the British.
events_leading_up_to_war: In 1807, France and Spain signed the Treaty of Fontainebleau, which allowed French troops to pass through Spain on their way to invade Portugal.
Napoleon's decision to replace the Spanish king, Charles IV, with his own brother Joseph, sparked widespread rebellion in Spain.
The Spanish people, backed by British forces under Wellington, initiated a guerrilla war against the French occupation.

result.general: Allied victory (Spain, Portugal, and the United Kingdom)
result.territorial_changes: French forces were expelled from Spain and Portugal, and Joseph Bonaparte was removed from the Spanish throne.
result.long_term_effects: The war weakened Napoleon's influence in the Iberian Peninsula and contributed to the eventual downfall of the French Empire.

Spanish_Empire: Francisco de Goya (commander of the Spanish guerrillas)
Pedro de Alcántara Álvarez de Toledo

French_Empire.ships: French naval presence in the Mediterranean

major_battles.name: Battle of Salamanca
major_battles.description: A decisive victory for the British and Spanish forces under the Duke of Wellington, which forced the French to retreat from Spain.
major_battles.outcome: Allied victory, the French were forced to retreat from the Iberian Peninsula.

major_battles.name: Battle of Vitoria
major_battles.description: An important Allied victory that led to the final expulsion of French forces from Spain and Portugal.
major_battles.outcome: Allied victory, Napoleon's hold on Spain and Portugal was shattered.

texts.name: Napoleon's Letters and Orders
texts.details: Napoleon's correspondence during the Peninsular War provides critical insights into his strategic decisions and military maneuvers.

texts.name: British Military Reports
texts.details: Reports from the British military, particularly from Wellington, document the campaigns and battles during the war.

archaeological_evidence.description: Weapons, cannonballs, and personal items found on battlefields such as Salamanca and Vitoria confirm the details of the major confrontations.
Monuments and memorials in Spain and Portugal commemorate the victory and resilience of the local forces during the war.

historical_texts.name: The Peninsular War by Sir Charles Oman
historical_texts.details: An authoritative history that explores the strategy, battles, and political implications of the Peninsular War.

historical_texts.name: Wellington: The Iron Duke by Richard Holmes
historical_texts.details: A biography of Duke of Wellington, focusing on his role in the Peninsular War and his leadership in defeating Napoleon.

political: The war contributed to Napoleon's downfall, with Spain and Portugal regaining their independence.
The British became recognized as a dominant power in European affairs, and the Bourbon monarchy was restored in Spain.
long_term_effects: The Peninsular War had significant consequences for Spain and Portugal, leading to instability in the Spanish Empire and the beginning of the Latin American Wars of Independence.
The war weakened Napoleon's influence and was a key factor leading to his eventual defeat in 1814.

military: The Peninsular War is considered one of the most complex and costly campaigns of the Napoleonic Wars, characterized by its use of guerrilla warfare and the strategic brilliance of Wellington.
It marked a turning point in Napoleon's fortunes, as his forces were stretched thin, leading to costly defeats.
political: The war severely weakened French dominance in Spain and Portugal, and contributed to the larger downfall of Napoleon.
It led to the restoration of the Bourbon monarchy in Spain, and greatly influenced European politics in the post-Napoleonic era.
cultural: The war had a lasting impact on Spanish and Portuguese cultures, as it spurred national identities and independence movements across Latin America.
Wellington became a national hero in the United Kingdom, and the Peninsular War played a significant role in British military and imperial history.
